title: How to Clean a Food Hopper

steps.headline: Set the feeder to the “pause” mode if it’s automatic.
steps.description: If your pet feeder is automatic and has electronically-controlled settings, press the switch or button to set the feeder on its “pause” mode. This will keep the feeder from trying to dispense food through the hopper while you’re cleaning it. If the feeder doesn’t have a “pause” mode, you can turn it off or unplug it instead.

steps.headline: Take the hopper off its base.
steps.description: Most automatic pet feeders have a release button or latch that allows you to remove the hopper from its base. If your pet food feeder has this option, remove the hopper from the base to make it easier to clean thoroughly. It’s particularly important that you remove the hopper from the base if the base contains any electronic components.

steps.headline: Remove any leftover food from the hopper.
steps.description: If there’s any food in the hopper that hasn’t been dispensed, turn the hopper over to dump it out. You can also remove the leftover food by manually dispensing it or by scooping it out with a spoon. If the food is still fresh, you can place it off to the side in a container and reload it into the hopper after it’s clean.

steps.headline: Run the hopper through the dishwasher if it’s dishwasher safe.
steps.description: First, check the instruction manual to see if the hopper is dishwasher safe. If it is, you can run it through the dishwasher on the same wash cycle you use for your dishes. The heat from the dishwasher can ruin some types of plastic and acrylic hoppers, so make sure you check the instructions before putting the hopper in the dishwasher.

steps.headline: Hand wash the hopper with dish soap if it’s not dishwasher safe.
steps.description: Using a dime-sized amount of dish soap and a sponge or clean cloth, scrub the hopper under running sink water. Once you’ve scrubbed off any residue, rinse the soapy water off with clean running water. Use a soft sponge or cloth to avoid scratching or damaging the hopper.

steps.headline: Leave the hopper out to air dry before putting it back on its base.
steps.description: If you hand washed your pet food hopper or if it’s still moist from the dishwasher, place it on a clean towel to dry completely. Make sure it’s completely dry before following the instructions to put the hopper back on it’s base.

steps.headline: Clean your pet food hopper every 6 months.
steps.description: While the feeding bowl needs to be cleaned more often, you only need to wash your pet feeder’s hopper once every 6 months, or as needed to remove clogs. Food particles and oils can build up over time, so it’s important that you wash the hopper to keep it in working condition. If you notice that your pet food hopper isn’t dispensing food as quickly, you may need to wash it more frequently to keep it from getting jammed.

steps.headline: Turn the machine off and remove any remaining food from the hopper.
steps.description: First, turn off or unplug the soft-serve dispensing machine. Then, open the machine according to the instructions so you’re able to access the contents of the hopper. Remove any food that’s still in the hopper by rinsing it down with cold water. If the food in the hopper isn’t soft enough to wash down with cold water, you can also scoop it out with a spoon. How you’ll open the machine to access the hopper varies depending on the type of dispenser you have. Therefore, it’s important that you follow the instructions carefully.

steps.headline: Pour warm water into the hopper 2 to 3 times.
steps.description: First, fill a bucket or large cup with warm water. Then, pour the water down into the hopper, pouring in a circular motion around the sides to remove any lingering residue. Repeat this process 2 to 3 times until all the food residue has washed down through the dispenser. If your hopper has a stopper, such as a frozen yogurt machine lever, open the lever so that the dispenser is opened up and the warm water and food residue can rinse out.

steps.headline: Mix your sanitizing solution according to the instructions.
steps.description: First, check the manufacturer’s instruction manual that came with your wet food hopper to see what type of sanitizer they recommend. Many soft-serve hopper sanitizers need to be diluted by mixing 2 parts of warm water for every 1 part of the solution in a clean bowl or bucket. If your soft-serve hopper manufacturer doesn’t recommend a specific type or brand of sanitizer, you can choose one of many commercial food hopper sanitizers that are widely available online and at many restaurant supply shops. While most sanitizers need to be diluted with water, some manufacturers recommend brands that come pre-mixed.

steps.headline: Scrub the hopper with a cleaning brush and the sanitizing solution.
steps.description: Using a cleansing brush, applying the sanitizing solution across the inside of the hopper, scrubbing as needed to remove any stains or hard spots. You can apply the solution by dipping the cleansing brush into the sanitizing solution, or by closing the hoppers dispenser and pouring some of the solution into the hopper, dipping the brush into the solution at the bottom as needed. Once you’ve scrubbed the inside of the hopper with a brush, open the dispenser to let the sanitizing solution flow out.

steps.headline: Pour in the remaining solution and run the clean cycle.
steps.description: If your machine has a self-clean cycle option, pour the rest of the sanitizing solution into the machine as instruction by the owner’s manual. Then, run the clean cycle for 5 to 10 minutes to allow the solution to flow through the hopper and disinfect it. If your machine doesn’t have a clean cycle, pour the remaining sanitizing solution into the hopper to drain out any debris and residue you lifted with the scrub brush.

steps.headline: Drain the sanitizer out and flush the hopper with water 2 to 3 times.
steps.description: Once the clean cycle is complete, open the dispenser at the bottom of the hopper to drain out the sanitizing solution. Then, rinse the hopper with a bucket or cup of water 2 to 3 times, or until all the solution is rinsed off.

steps.headline: Allow the sanitized hopper to air dry completely overnight.
steps.description: Even after rinsing the solution out of the hopper with water, there will likely be some sanitizer residue still inside. Therefore, it’s important that you leave the hopper to air dry so the solution will continue sanitizing the hopper before breaking down over time. Make sure the hopper is completely dry before plugging your machine back in or turning it on and refilling it with wet food.

steps.headline: Clean your soft-serve hopper at least 3 times per week.
steps.description: To keep the hopper sanitized and to prevent any clogging, repeat this process to clean the hopper at least 3 times per week. If you’re using the hopper for commercial use, however, such as an ice cream or yogurt shop, your jurisdiction may require daily cleaning. Therefore, make sure that you check with your local authorities to see how often you legally need to clean the hopper.

methods.name: Using Dish Soap to Wash a Dry Food Hopper

steps.headline: Remove any leftover food and food particles.
steps.description: If there’s any dry food still in the hopper, remove it by dispensing it out of the hopper or scooping it out with a spoon. Then, use a clean towel to wipe down the inside of the hopper to remove some of the lingering food particles. If your hopper is mesh, use a dry towel to wipe down the inside of the hopper. Using a damp cloth can cause small particles, such as ground coffee or crumbs, to stick further in the machine and cause it to jam. If it’s easier, you can wait and dump out any remaining food once you’ve taken the hopper off its base.

steps.headline: Take the hopper off its base if it’s removable.
steps.description: If your dry food hopper is removable from its base, follow the instructions in the owner’s manual to remove it. This will make it much easier to clean the hopper without getting any other parts, particularly any electronics, wet. Some dry food hoppers, such as tabletop commercial cereal dispensers, do not contain electronic parts and may not be removable from their base. If this is the case, you can generally clean the hopper on its base along with the rest of the dispenser.

steps.headline: Scrub the hopper with dish soap and hot water.
steps.description: Place the hopper in the sink and squirt a dime-sized amount of dish soap inside. Wash the hopper with hot water, scrubbing as needed with a soft cloth or sponge to remove any food particles or residue sticking to the sides. Avoid using an abrasive cloth or sponge, as this may scratch and damage the hopper. Avoid using an ammonia-based cleaner, particularly if the hopper is made of acrylic or plastic, as this can damage the material.

steps.headline: Rinse the soapy water off with clean running water.
steps.description: Place the hopper under running water in the sink to rinse the soap off. Make sure that you rinse both the inside and outside, as well as the dispenser at the bottom to remove all the soap from the hopper.

steps.headline: Leave the hopper to air dry completely on a clean towel.
steps.description: Once all the soap suds are washed off, lay a clean towel out on a flat surface and place the hopper on top to dry. Leave it dry overnight or for several hours. Make sure that the hopper is completely dry before putting it back on its base. If the hopper is still wet at all, it could drip water into the dispenser and cause any metal parts to rust over time.
